Use the B.E.A.N.S method.
Beans
Empty carbs if you have to
Assorted veg
Spices.

If i had ten dollars I'd buy beans and whatever stewing vegetables i could find
If i had fifteen dollars I'd buy salt, chilli and lime juice and made a weeks worth of vegitarians chilli.

>>18889571
I have the NS-LHC05XT, which is the Indian model. The Zojirushi in your picture is the NS-LGCO5XB which is the American model. The difference is that one has a jasmine rice button and the other has a steel cut oats button.

You list 3-cup size as a con, but actually it's a pro. Unless you have a family you'll never use all 3 cups. Keep in mind that it's talking about dry cups -- that's 1900 calories of rice. You're really gonna eat more than that in one sitting?

If you're not gonna eat more than that in one sitting, the smaller cup size is actually better than the bigger cup size. 1 cup of rice cooks better in the 3-cup pot than in the 5-cup pot. That's because less of it is "on the bottom" and more of it is "in the middle." It also stays more steamed since it's more cozy. I bought that one specifically because it's the smallest pot cooker I could find and it's a phenomenal device.

Single layer of chips, medium sprinkle of toppings, thin layer of cheese, 425 for 5 minutes. You're going to have better nachos faster if you do N batches than if you do N layers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18890026
The secret* is good separate layers
Also spray oil on the sheet pan or baking dish
Open the bag of chips from the bottom
Use the crumbled chips to make a base layer
On this layer goes real cheese, shredded
Then build another layer with whole chips
Another layer of real cheese
If you're using beans, they go next
Then meat
Then nacho cheese, the fucking God-awful, but delicious queso sauce dip stuff
Then another layer of chips, real cheese, beans, meat, queso
Maybe do this a third time
For the topmost layer, in addition to your chips, real cheese, beans, meat, and queso, add a final real cheese sprinkle, and well-drained Ro-Tel tomatoes
Bake it at 350 until it's warmed through
Garnish it with sliced green onions
Don't use salsa or anything else too runny
People can add salsa, black olives, sour cream, cilantro, chopped white onion, and/or pickled jalapeno, on their own plate

*It's not a secret, just avoid wet, sloppy ingredients, you shouldn't have to eat it with a spoon; the tortilla chips should be the only utensil necessary

>australian answer
I grew up on an olive farm, so I grab another 2L cask from family whenever I run low

On the rare occasion I need to buy some I'll get cobrams estate or red island as good quality at their price point.

The easymode rules:
>but actual olive oil (looking at you america)
>buy as local as reasonable, anything imported will usually be older
>buy as close to the harvest/crushing date as possible. The 'best before' date is fine to compare across brands.
Age is key for flavour. If you want some sharp grassy flavours, get an early press as young as possible. If all you want is cooking oil, 2 years old is fine.

>>18861512
if its buds, 5g/100ml 80-85c, 15seconds then either +5 or +15 seconds with each additional steep. buds can get very bitter but i think they do better with longer gongfu steepings.
if its leaves the same but you can use full boiling, but tend to do better with shorter steeps. some people also simmer the leaves in a saucepan for a long time.

i find whites to be the hardest to brew right because they all seem to require different parameters where as black/oolongs/green ect call brew up well with the same parameters i.e all blacks behave the same, all whites behave differently at least for me

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18861512
>>18862215
You need to full soak the buds to get them to start extracting, which takes a pretty long time. Depending on your preference, you can do a fairly long hard rinse, boiling water for 30s or more depending on how dense your buds are, or you can do a short rinse, 5-10s at with boiling water, then a long brew, say 30s with boiling water. Once the leaves seem soaked through, they'll noticeably extract much faster. Do 10-15s brews here, if your tea is pleasant but thin, use more leaf, I brew with a very high ratio of leaf to water for baihao yinzhen. If it starts to be astringent or develop off flavors, you can do your main brews at around 90C instead. Once the leaves start to thin out, I like to do a single minute long brew, then a five minute brew and end it.

It will depend on the leaves you have, but the basic profile should look like that. Long brew to soak the leaves and get them to open up a bit, successions of much shorter brews, a few long brews. At close to boiling or boiling water, but feel free to lower the temperature if you feel you need to.

>>18871841
My biggest advice is that real, professional tasting is hard, and you shouldn't worry about giving brief or simple tasting notes. Trying to force it doesn't really work. When you're starting out you'll mostly give notes like woody, nutty, earthy etc. as you taste more stuff and have a better calibration, you'll start to find different sorts of flavors that can be consistent across different teas that you'll want to look for words to describe. I think it's fun, but a lot of the cultural and focus around tasting is people like Mei Leaf, who do it as a performance and not as any serious exercise. China has a robust culture around tea tasting and evaluation, but it mostly hasn't been exported from what I've seen.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: what's the general difference in taste between small and large leaf ripe pu-erhs?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18873668
This is very general
Smaller leafs and buds, stronger, more bitter, infuses faster, runs out out flavor in less brews. Larger leaves + stems, sweeter, more mellow, smoother, less strong brews but more of them.
But its going to vary based on processing, fermentation level, the batch of tea leaves used etc.

Like I said, I've experienced first-hand in various green tea drinking countries in Asia like Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan and China, that they don't brew at a specific temperature, they just pour boiling water straight into the pot. If you go to these countries and suggest using 90 degree water you will just get laughed out of the room like the autist you are.

From my own personal experience, boiling water doesn't make green tea bitter. What makes it bitter is:
- shitty quality tea leaves, usually from a bag
- not allowing the leaves room to expand, such as using an infuser basket
- adding too many leaves to the pot

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Tea beginner here.
I tried and liked Bigelow's oolong, but Twinings is lighter, less earthy, and more of a green tea flavor to it. Is there supposed to be that much variation in oolong?
I prefer Bigelow's to Twining's here. What beginner-level brands should I look for?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18877041
oolong is one of the most varied categories of tea, because it can be more or less oxidized. the less oxidized stuff is closer to green tea, more oxidized to black tea generally. also, oolong can be roasted to various degrees, which can also change the flavor completely. there are many different types of oolong, some of them can be very fresh and smell of flowers and fruit, while others are bready, nutty, sweet or even minetal in taste

you generally shouldn't buy tea by prepackaged supermarket brands if you want to buy good quality stuff. you should be buying it from trusted vendors, who you can find in the pastebin.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18877041
>Is there supposed to be that much variation in oolong?
yes you can get big variation in tea picked from the same mountain. oolongs typically come either as fermented 'green tea' or oxidised fermented 'black tea'
>What beginner-level brands should I look for?
loose will always be better than bagged, get a gaiwan or brewing basket that fits in your mug. vahdam is good for indian and sells on amazon, im guessing as your just starting out you wouldn't want to dive right in to importing from chinese suppliers. look out for iron goddess of mercy/Tieguanyin and Da Hong Pao/Big Red Robe. you'll be able to get both off amazon/tea houses/chinese stores although buying off an actual tea seller will give better quality and probably a little cheaper/quality

>How exactly does one pry apart a tuo?
Put the tuo down with the dent on the bottom, go around about an inch from the edge with the pick and push downwards/pry outwards. Once you have the loosest tea around the edges removed you can either pry a layer off the top or just break the rest into chunks with your fingers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18887570
>looking at an induction plate + tetsubin setup to replace my 100% plastic electric kettle currently
Not that anon but this is a pretty sweet setup. I guess you could also look at an electric heating element + a clay/cermaic/stoneware kettle as well they both have pros and cons. With cast iron you don't have to worry about temperature shock (maybe if you put ice cubes in a hot kettle or something) so you can refill and boil more water in the middle of a session, but you do have to worry about rust, so you have to make sure to empty the kettle after use. With clay you have to worry about temp shock so if your kettle is already hot you have to refill it with water that has already been heated, but then you don't have to worry about rust.
Personally im too lazy for either so i use an electric kettle that is 100% steel on the inside.
https://www.amazon.com/Secura-Electric-Stainless-Protection-K15-F1E/dp/B087BRBX4Q/

>>18889866
how does the taste differ from a more typically stored ripe?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18891391
With Hong Kong traditional storage you get a kind of earthy soil flavor, the tea is very rounded out and mellow and the taste of the storage is fairly prominent. Sometimes you get prerty strong camphor notes but that's not necessarily ideal. You definitely get some aspects of mustyness or wet storage taste and it usually benefits froma solid rinse before you start brewing it, depending on what your tolerance for funk its. Think earthy, beet root, root cellar, it's a very transformative process and needs to be managed by somone with a lot of experience and understanding of traditional storage for best resuts. Each HK vendor will have a sort of specific house flavor based on their exact process which is pretty interesting.
Teadb has a decent post about it
https://teadb.org/what-to-expect-from-traditionally-stored-tea/
https://teadb.org/some-thoughts-problems-about-traditionally-stored-puerh/
If you want to try some ripe from YOT this is my favorite of the several i tried and its on the more affordable end of his range. (Prices are in hong kong dollars)
https://yeeonteaco.com/collections/puerh/products/2008-ripe-puerh-tea-brick-jinggu-factory

Imagine this scenario: you're a soldier in Vietnam, sweeping through a patch of jungle with your unit. Suddenly Charlie pops out of the trees and battle ensues, 10 minutes of life or death combat, bombs are blowing up all around you, you see your Lieutenant trying to stuff his intestines back into his body while crying for his mom, your buddy is roasting gooks alive when his flamethrower pack catches a stray round and he explodes, eventually you look down and see you've caught a couple of slugs to the chest but you never even realized because of the sheer amount of adrenaline surging through your body. You awaken some time later. It could be minutes, hours, days, even a week. You survived. You're the last living man on a battlefield strewn with corpses, friend and foe alike, of which those with the least bloated and maggot-infested have long since been scavenged by man and jungle beast alike. Imagine the smell, that rotting putrid meat smell, the dried blood rotten fruit stench permeating all around the wet ripe jungle mud and coating your nose and skin and eyes and tongue with its 100-degree tropical humidity.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18884341
ok, first I chuckled, but then I realized you're not trolling, so lets break it down, shall we?
>fry some onions and garlic in butter
first of all, not some onions, but you caramelize onions.
second, not some garlic, but garlic and ginger, and you do these separetely, only for around 30 seconds or so, otherwise you will burn them.
And no, not butter, but ghee. If you don't have ghee, use regular oil, don't use butter, lol.
>add curry powder and let it combine and cook for a bit
wait, actually good advice? well, almost. for 500g of meat I recommend 2 tablespoons of good quality curry powder, but actually I recommend adding around 200ml of passata, cooking it for a couple of minutes, and then adding spices, which then you cook a bit more to get out their true flavours.
>add milk
for krishna's sake, never, absolutely, n e v e r add milk.
add chicken, then when no longer pink, dilute everything with a bit of water
>Then finish cooking seared chicken in it (thighs work great)
total gibberish, I'm not even bother deciphering it, it does says chicken though, so no, that's the wrong time to put the chicken in.
thighs do work great though. 5 points for slytherin (that's where I imagine you would be after writing such low quality recipe)
>Let the chicken simmer in there for 30 minutes
wtf, I love dry mushy chicken? just kidding, give it 20 minutes top.
>The curry powder thickens the sauce by itself so you don't have to do anything else to it.
o boy, there we go. curry powder will not thicken the sauce whatsoever. not even a bit, nope, runny, watery, curry on your way sir!
remember that mythical passata we added earlier? yep, that's your main thickener.
>Pile it on rice and w'Allah
first of all, you forgot to add a little bit of heavy cream, just a tad to mellow the spices.
and second of all, no, don't pile it on rice, pour it into a bowl and add a bit at the time on your rice platter, next to the rice. you want easy access to plain rice to cleanse the palette.

>>18884388
So to clarify you could put basically any combo of these ingredients and make a curry dish, probably by order of my listing. Honestly just looking at it, it's probably correct to assume greatest to smallest by volume added to the average dish.

If you already cook a decent amount you should have nearly all of this in your spice cabinet and fridge. Practice by looking up a few recipes, aloo gobi, aloo palak, saag paneer, vindaloo, etc. Then you'll get a sense for "this type of curry uses more cardamom" or "sri lankan curries use way more ground coriander:" Then once you cook a few of these and understand the flavor profiles you can cook basically any dish like that by feel. It's also wild because it actually shares a lot in common with many mexican dishes and chinese food. Idk why people try to make shit so complicated.

posts.com:
>>18885145
>jaggery is just sugar, black salt is just salt, hing tastes like shallots/onions
Wrong on every fucking count. Jaggery is sugar in the same sense that brown sugar is the same as white sugar. Black salt is mostly salt, but has a much different taste due to the other stuff in it and is not a good salt substitute. The flavor of hing is vaguely onion like, but the texture sure isn't like an onion's. You might as well say minced garlic and onion powder are the same.

While most of the things I listed are in garam masala, you're not going to be able to temper right without whole spices, and for that you're going to want things like whole cloves, whole cumin seeds, cinnamon, etc.

In conclusion, deal with it!

>>18885123
The sauce that makes up the curry is usually a very thick pureed vegetable stock made from onions, garlic, carrots, tomato and bell peppers that spices are then added to. The meat or veg of the dish is usually fried in ghee with a garlic & ginger puree, has about a tablespoon of whatever spice mixture is required for the dish and then 1/4 cup of condensed tomato paste and a couple of ladles of that vegetable stock are added in until they get the right consistency/colour. There's a lot more veg in an Indian curry than almost any other kind of takeaway.

Medium high - high medium. It should sizzle loudly as soon as you put the fish in and you should be able to feel the heat with your hand an inch from the pan.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1. creamy salmon pasta. cut in cubes, sear, add whatever vegetals you like. sauce is some sliced onion boiled in heavy cream for 10-15 minutes, then smoothed out with an immersion blender. use whatever pasta you like, spaghetti works for me
2. raw. cut into cubes, put into a bowl, add a couple of teaspoons of mustard, stir around until it's all coated. serve along a dipping sauce made of soy sauce, mirin and rice vinegar
3. cut into big pieces, make norwegian butter sauce
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Pm0JqeChb_Q

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18887724
I do salmon two ways:

-Juice of half a lemon before cooking
-Drizzle of olive oil over the lemon
-Salt, pepper, dried dill
-Broil, or bake at 400
-Juice the other half of the lemon over the salmon fresh after it's done cooking

or:

-Mix up soy sauce, miso paste, rice vinegar into a marinade
-Coat the salmon with the marinade
-Drizzle with sesame oil
-Sprinkle on black pepper, onion powder, ginger powder, and sesame seeds
-Broil, or bake at 400
-Drizzle with wasabi sauce after it's done cooking

posts.com:

I'm a fan of Old Bay.
I'll usually smoke my salmon, but it goes like this.

Brine mixture over night with wine and soy sauce.
Open air for 2 hours for scaling
1/4 cup brown sugar, 1/4 cup Old Bay, thoroughly coated
Cold smoked for 3-4 hours
Oven cooked for 15 minutes at 450f

I'm sure even if you skipped the the smoking, you'd get good results.

2 inches of water, half a lemon, salt, thyme, dill, and garlic.
Poach the salmon until cooked, then remove intact.
Strain and clarify the poaching liquid with 1 egg.
Add gelatin to the liquid, pour over salmon and place in fridge for 20 minutes until soft.
Slice up 1 hard boiled egg, shove into the gelatin.
Place in fridge and harden for 2 hours.
Serve.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
No, kabaret is not a common food item here. I don't think I've seen it served once in my entire life. Regular sweet gelatine is more common than that.

Traditional norwegian food items consists of a lot of lamb and pig meat (made in any way but often cured or preserved in some way), fish, cheese, flatbread and regular bread, potatoes, root vegetables, game meat, pancakes, simple cakes and cookies, meatballs, berries and berry sauces, savoury sauces, porridge and other stuff that is eaten commonly all over europe.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Ever since I was a little kid, people noticed how much I loved ice water. My mother often remarked that I was “always thirsty,” and it was true: I couldn’t get enough of that primal, pure satisfaction of The Quench. Drinking water. And as I came to understand as a mere boy, if one is quenched by water, one is doubly quenched by cold water. For my entire life I have prepared my water by completely filling the glass with ice, then finishing with only enough water to fill the spaces between the chunks of ice: CRUCIALLY you must let it stand for several minutes, or until small condensation begins to fog the outside of the glass (but before the condensation droplets become large) to give the water molecules time to be affected by the ice’s temperature. It amounts to a very small amount of water; perhaps two or three gulps worth at most, per fill, but each and every molecule of liquid water has been chilled by contact with solid water: it physically could not be any colder, and thus more quenching, without losing liquid form.
I like to chew on the ice cubes too. I’ve snapped 3 teeth in half in my life time just by chewing ice. We defeated the wrong enemy.

>>18877773
I came up with the idea for Peat Monster, nice to see it mentioned here. The first batch was a 50/50 blend of Caol Ila and Clynelish (or maybe Ardmore, it was a long time ago lol), both about 10 or 15 years old, aged in ex-bourbon, and bottled at cask strength. It was just called Monster. John Glaser, the founder, didn’t want to make it at first because he didn’t personally enjoy peaty whisky. It turned out to be the blend that put him on the map, so he decided to make it regular production item as Peat Monster, with some water added to lower the proof.

Depends on the roast. I'd give it at least two weeks. You're trying to avoid an extra variable(offgassing) that will affect your consistency. >The weight loss and degassing rate of the sample roasted at medium speed to a light roast degree was also measured over a longer period of 800 h; after 800 h, a total of 3.4 mg/g weight loss from degassing was measured. The degassing rate at this point was still 2 μg g–1 h–1. This shows that even when degassing is conducted at elevated temperatures (35 °C), light roasted whole coffee beans are still degassing 1 month after roasting. The impact of the roast speed on the amount of degassed CO2 is consistent with findings of Wang et al. and confirm that for medium to dark roast degrees, faster roasted beans degas faster compared to slower roasted beans. The degassing of light roasted coffee is, in contrast to dark and medium roasts, smaller in absolute terms and less impacted by the roasting speed; no increasing trend from a slow to a fast roast profile was observed (Figure 5a, light roast). posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18889540
Darker roasts will offgas very quickly, but the exposed surface oils will oxidize and go rancid just as quickly. Thats the skunky stale smell you get from grocery store bags. Spoiled plant fat doesn't taste good, drink those within a month off roasting. Anything lighter than that will be fine a good while longer if you're not constantly getting in the bag exposing it to fresh oxygen. Thats where shit like airscape containers(anything sealed with a one way valve really) come in handy. You're not letting fresh oxygen react with the roasted plant fats inside your beans, while letting them vent carbon dioxide. co2 doesn't taste good. Thats why you stir crema on espresso into the shot. Its a sour bitter layer of trapped gasses preventing you from getting to the actual flavors you're trying to extract. Resting will depend on the roast and density of the bean. There's no harm in testing how they taste once a week, just avoid constant exposure to fresh oxygen. Also why people like the meme single dosing tubes.
https://www.wired.com/2009/10/your-tongue-the-carbon-dioxide-sensor/

>>18889137
Buy what you can drink within 2-4 weeks. By the time roasted coffee gets to you it has rested enough. Coffee is rested for 1-3 days after roasting for the flavors to develop. Do not confuse this with the spergy weeks-long CO2 off-gassing espresso dorks do. They do this so that they can more precisely dial in their shots at the expense of losing flavor. I repeat: they are losing flavor as a trade off for replicability of espresso shot extraction. The volatile aromatic compounds that give good, fresh coffee its taste are lost over time. It is very noticeable after about 2-4 weeks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
An egg dumplings recipe that my mother got from her grandmother which originated from either Germany or Russia. Can't remember where exactly. Simply take a couple eggs, a couple tablespoons of milk and cup or 2 of flour, beat the eggs and milk together, add flour and beat until thick, scoop out some portions and throw them into boiling water pot and cook for 15-30 minutes. When done cooking scoop out dumplings with spoon with a strainer to remove water and put in bowl applying butter and pepper to your liking.

Been thinking about changing the recipe up abit and adding more too it but I think it's pretty peak poor people food as is.

Cereal, instant ramen, homemade pizzas using the cheapest pizza dough mix, jarred sauce, and store brand cheese available, canned ravioli, spaghetti-os, sandwiches, everything the cheapest possible off-brand from the discount grocery store that only sold whatever cheap shit they could get that week.

I was fully aware how shit our situation was from a pretty young age, decided when I moved out I wasn't going to do that shit anymore and started teaching myself to cook immediately.

Oh yeah, you fucking knew. When you are relying on school free lunch/breakfast to get you by, you sure as fuck knew you were poor. Hotdogs, beans, cheap ground meat. Anything on sale. Margarine. Later on it got replaced with eating out because we came into money.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Grew up almost hillbilly poor but never realized it. My mom had a nice but small house. We ate a lot of beans and pasta and eggs from our coop. We also grew a lot of zucchini, tomatoes and potatoes and had fruit trees. She canned a lot but i thought that was just how everyone ate so I didn't really know any better. I look back on it all fondly

Two embarrassing stories, our school had some kind of park outing. They ordered those giant 9 foot subway sandwiches for the class. Everyone was supposed to chip in a couple of dollars but my brother and I had nothing so we had to eat our pb&j sandwiches while all the other kids feasted.
Second one I was spending the day at a friends house. They decide to go out to dinner to some pizza place. Told me it was a family thing and I could come along but couldn't eat with them I had to buy my own food.
Now that I think about it that family were kind of assholes. That wasn't the first time they fucked with me. They knew we were dirt poor and they were rich. Probably why they never let me hang out with their kid again after that.
Being a poor kid living in a relatively well off neighborhood was hell. Everyone I knew at school/church was always going on ski trips and shit and we never got to go along with anything.

>>18876648
i wasn't particularly poor myself but my parents both grew up either very poor or in a family massive enough to have to worry about food costs between so many kids. as a result they continued a habit as adults of buying the absolute lowest priced value foods to the cent they could find even though they never needed to by the time me or my brother were old enough to care. they were actually really resourceful when it came to cooking so the food was good but occasionally i got some unfortunate stuff such as

>meat frozen so long it tasted like nothing by the time we did eat it
>the occasional expired dollar store food, never understood this because there was a legitimate grocery store literally next door with comparable prices
>mom would always yell at me for taking a pack of 2 poptarts instead of just 1 to school at age 13, where my morning was basically leaving the house at 5am for a long ass bus trip and no school lunch until noon
>incredibly low amounts of salt or spices ever used, didn't grasp this until it clicked why homemade plain chicken tasted nothing like restaurant chicken
>yelling over who opened a cereal
>yelling over who finished a pack of anything, but also yelling over who left a small amount of a pack of anything
>insistence that the same coffee grounds be reused, i thought coffee was just shit water until adulthood because this was obviously not good
>the occasional bizarre leftovers creation that was hit or miss, later learned that this was usually a result of my dad being bored. he still does this to this day and it's usually something pretty cool nowadays but he holds himself to such a high standard and expectations for what amounts to "mix of whatever is in the fridge"

however there was some stuff i really did like that i still eat now that im on my own, like cheap frozen fish and pierogis.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Not poor but I'm a social worker.
I've seen three "types" of home, in the first three family has some money but is dysfunctional, all the food is junk food, the freezer is full of pizza, the fridge is full of soft drink. This isn't nearly as expensive as you might imagine because of how calorie dense these foods acrually are. Kids skip meals, throw tantrums when food runs out, binge eat, get fat.

In the second type of home there's no money but at least one tired and stressed family member cooks. Often it's monotonous and totally unseasoned, boiled frozen vegetables, pasta, boiled eggs. Meat offcuts or frozen hotdogs in a pan, boiled potatoes. There's a variant for every ethnicity, but this is actually far better nutrition wise.

Third household is begging and stealing, everyone hoards and hides food, the only things in the fridge are moldy or fouled.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18881748
Buy in bulk, even cheaper brands are fine even if they don't taste as much. They also last very long so you're not wasting any of it.
The money I save by buying slightly less quality meat for a month can be used to buy said oils and spices that will last several months so when you got that down upgrade meat as budget allows. We're not talking about a full cabinet of 20 spices either, just the most basic ones. I'm assuming salt and pepper are not included so rosemary, thyme, oregano, chili and one or two more after preference. Obviously you can't expect getting fresh stuff constantly unless planting it yourself.

I just know I'd prefer more basic meals with a larger choice of spices and oils to make variations than simply upgrading the meat quality slightly and not having said stuff. Worst case you can get piece by piece as budget allows since it, again, lasts very long (oils and spices).

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18876648
Grew up fairly poor, 2 children single mom on teacher salary. I don't think there was really any consistent thread to what we ate. Mom cooked the vast majority of meals, either from scratch or instant, and we didn't eat much meat. The stuff she'd make from scratch was mostly soups and stews, and we ate a lot of rice and vegetables. We still could eat at mcdonalds or get pizza sometimes, but it was uncommon enough that it felt like a treat when we did. If there was anything that was missing it's snacks. She'd never buy soda, juice, cookies, or chips with the groceries. The only time we'd get a dessert after a meal is if we went to subway she'd get a single cookie to split between the three of us. If I went to a friend's house and they had snacks and sodas it seemed like the height of luxury. All in all I think she did a really good job since I only really realized how poor we were looking back on it. Even though she wasn't the greatest cook, food anxiety was never an issue for us and we developed fairly healthy eating habits.

>>18876648
We grew up rich but had to eat poor. We even had to help out with the cooking. We never got fast food, popcorn, cola, chips, sandwiches from Subway, Starbucks coffee or ketchup from a bottle (exceptions were Christmas, Easter, and our anniversaries in July and August). We had to help plant, reap, peel and pickle onions, leek, cornichons, make pig stews, sausages and candy with paws, ears, tails and blood. We had to learn which fish and shellfish are in season and how to peel, fillet and batter them.

To this day I spend 1/10th per month on food of what poor people spend (source: /ck/). Yet I eat like ancient European nobility (source: nunya).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Mum did her best raising 5 kids by herself, and we had food on the table which is more than a lot can say so I'd never complain about it especially now. She put herself through medical school to become a nurse to provide for us, she was hard working and I appreciate everything she did.

Pajeet Canadian. My family was poor but we ate three full meals a day plus some goyslop. Rarely ever ordered takeout, maybe 2 slices of pizza or 3 donuts once every few weeks that we would share between the 6 of us.

Dinner was a fresh beef/chicken curry and fresh white rice. When we got really broke, no meat curry, it was tuna mixed into Dahl (lentil soup). Often with lettuce and cucumbers. And apple juice (a 2L can was a $1).

Lunch the next day was leftover dinner but the curry would be reheated with a cup of water mixed in so it was wateryyyy. The curry was made thin originally too. So we got like two ounces of meat per meal max.

Lunch packed for school was a strawberry jam sandwich.

>>18888686
Somalis eat a banana with literally every dish. It's weird, but primitive countries generally don't have a rigid distinction between sweet and savoury dishes the way they do. In some regions of Uganda, boiled bananas are their staple carb, they eat dishes such as boiled bananas with beans.

Another weird thing done with spaghetti in Africa is the Ethiopian way of eating it. They eat spaghetti in tomato sauce but the whole thing is served on an injera (very thin pancake made of teff wheat, with a sour taste because the dough is left to ferment for a few days). See pic related for an example.

>>18891068
>adding tomato to ceviche makes it mexican
The Mexican ceviche is not simply a tomato on top of the "original" recipe though. Not only is the tomato incorporated into the dish, other ingredients are also substituted from the south American variant due to differing availability. For example, in Peru (claims to have invented it), they also add hot peppers that Mexicans did not traditionally have access to.
>adding cream to carbonara makes it british/american
It's still Italian with cream. Yes, Italians did make it with cream themselves (albeit less commonly) despite what LARPing purists would have you believe, there are published Italian recipe books that instruct adding cream.

>>18861195
Didn’t drink until I was 17, at the after party to my high school ball (I guess burgers would call it prom). Then I got the taste for it.
Was fine for 2 years, alcoholic for 3, fine for another 3, alcoholic for another 3, and now I’m starting to clean up my act for my job. I know people here won’t sympathise or believe me, but my life has improved immensely in the last year through slow tapering.
I’m down to moderately drinking once a week, which is much better than being heavily dependant every day. It just took very small things like dropping a % per vol here and there, and buying slightly less every time you go to the shop.
I recently got back my taste for alcohol for the first time in god knows how long. I actually crave a good beer for the taste, or a good bourbon on the rocks.

tl;dr alcoholism sucks but you can still beat it by being smart. But I ain’t gonna blame you if you don’t want to, it’s your choice.

>>18890533
>Is there really no species of bacteria on Earth that can survive brine and is also harmful to ingest?

plenty of things potentially can, thats why you use a very specific amount of salt to water ratio that has been carefully figured out over the course of the entire history of humanity. what you are doing with your brine is creating the sweet spot for that particular kind of bacteria. they pop in, acidify the area converting sugars into vinegars, and eventually the brine reaches a point where its only hospitable to that specific strend. if you fuck up by letting things float, then other bacteria still have a chance.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18890816
it's not just the salt. the lactobacteria grows fairly quickly. it feeds off the sugars and makes carbon dioxide, pushing out oxygen out of the container and brine while also making it acidic. so any other bacteria needs to survive high salt content, low oxygen and also feed on something else than sugar. either that or be faster than the lacto.
just make sure you don't get mold and that nothing feels slimy and it should be fine. keep everything submerged

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18879577
If you ever wonder why Italians are anal about their food. This is why.

The original dish is called fegato alla Veneziana - Venetian style liver. You reduce Tropea (very mild) onions for 30 minutes in olive oil (from Garda lake) without letting them take any colour, remove them from the pan, turn up the heat and flash fry slabs (1cm thickness) of veal liver (the freshest possible) in the same pan. They should turn out rosé. Not saignant, not medium-rare, not rare. Rosé. Serve with the onions, freshly ground Lampong black pepper, sea salt and 25 yo aged balsamic vinegar from Modena. Serve with freshly ground polenta - mais sponcio (in the mountains surrounding Venice) or mais biancoperla (in the valley near the coast).

This dish has been maimed and killed, over and over and over again, for centuries. It's a children's favourite, when executed right. Which is rarely, if ever.

>>18888545
freeing up 80 a month gives you plenty of budget for one person per month. As long as you don't snack a lot w/ preprocessed stuff like cheez its and oreos, you don't eat out at restaurants, and you don't buy dumb shit like steak every night. Whole chickens are nice since you get 2 breasts 2 thighs 2 drums and like 4 wings, so it's a solid choice for ~$7. Chicken breast whole as a meal is good but it's much better chopped or sliced and used to add to other meals i.e. topping salads, in wraps, or with spaghetti. Chicken might be rising in price due to the whole bird shortage whatever, so look for alternatives for protein like fish, pork, and turkey. keep in mind the price per pound and the calories/protein per pound to give you a cals/protein per dollar. buy generic brand as much as you can, it isn't a huge step down. Don't start buying a ton of bulk shit if you don't need it. Yes it's cheaper by the pound, but if you're strapped for cash it's wiser to buy an $5 8oz bottle of olive oil that might last you a month compared to a 128oz jug of olive oil that'll last years. When you're well off, you can buy in bulk, but the high upfront cost disincentivizes buying in bulk when you're low. It's sad to say but you will have to take hits like that sometimes.

prior to some time in the 70's it was the way ALL steak was aged. then meat companies decided that it was too much of a pain in the ass, and they were losing money through trimming, and dry aged steak weighs less.

so they switched to wet aging. less waste, weighs more, less difficult.

now idiots treat dry aging like people do IPA's and overuse of hops. they think longer aging is better and the more funky tasting it is the better.

dry aging or any aging past 21 days is pointless, the steak is starting to rot after 21 days and you lose more meat to trimming.

inb4 "NuH UH!"

Hold on anon I’ll blow your ducking mind

-6 oz of canned anchovy high quality
- 6 oz of canned tuna high quality
-5 egg yolk
-3 tb of cold water
-shit ton of olive oil
-lemon juice
I may have forgotten the proportions but something like that

In a pan slowly mix the egg yolk and water on low heat until the mixture is creamy like in hollandaize, take it off regularly and mix to avoid scrambling

Then mix together the anchovy tuna and egg mixture in a food processor make sure to add oil in anchovy can. After it’s mixed slowly add in olive oil and lemon juice in very small amounts while pulsing in food processor. Stop when it’s creamy mixed and tastes good.

Serve on boiled eggs or very thinly cut veal.

I may have forgotten how exactly to do every step but that’s how’s probably done

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.sub: So despite the fact that I hat wine I made some Peposo.
posts.com:
It was fucking delicious. Will be making it again. I wanted to use beef short ribs, but my butcher was sold out so I made it with some nice chuck. The sauce came out very similar in flavor to A1 steak sauce in my opinion. Different enough that it was its own thing, but thats a close enough comparison if you want an idea of the flavor.
>Slice chuck into 3" or so size chunks
>Heavily salt and pepper, sear in a blazing hot dutch oven
>Sear in batches to avoid overcrowding the pan
>Remove to a bowl after searing
>Toss in one thinly sliced yellow onion, pinch of salt
>Use water released from onions to deglaze
>Cook onions until golden, building more fond
>Move onions to sides of pot to make a well in the center
>Toss in an absolute FUCKTON of roughly, freshly cracked black pepper
>Not enough. Add more. However much you think is too much, double it.
>Let the pepper bloom for 30 seconds or so
>Toss in a heaping tablespoon of tomato paste, cook until darkened slightly
>Oven on 325F
>Deglaze with red wine, I used a chianti as it's the tradition for this recipe
>Return beef, get wine to just beneath level of beef, bring to a summer
>Pop in oven, lid on for 1.5 hours
>Take lid off, stir/flip meat
>Every 30 minutes stir
>Cook until tender, mine took 3.5 hours total
>If sauce reduce too much add some beef stock or more wine, I had to in the last 30 minutes
>Remove beef, strain sauce into sauce pan to remove all the spent onion goop and rosemary, bay leaves that I forgot to mention
>If sauce is too thin, reduce
>If sauce is too thick thin it out with stock/wine
>Once perfect consistency is achieved, replace beef until warmed through
I served it very rusticly with just some chunks of crusty bread, but for a meal that only cost about $35 for the chuck roast and a bottle of wine this was seriously luxurious eating. Try it. Not my pic, btw. Didn't take any and it's all been digested.

>>18887112
ethanol boils at 78C, in cooking it’s not uncommon to reach those temperatures.
when the alcohol reaches it’s boiling point it starts evaporating rather quickly.
when the ethanol evaporates it goes from liquid to gas, and goes from being in your food to being in the air.
yes, there will still be a small amount left in the food, but not enough to have any noticable effect on your mind or body.

>in cooking it’s not uncommon to reach those temperatures

Worked at wholefoods before and after they got bought out by amazon. Initially they raised the starting wage before the state did. Everyone was happy as fuck, but I knew it was the beginning of the end.
>Annual pay rate reduced from 11% to 5.5% (this is the highest increase you can get...meaning you are most likely getting a 50 cent raise every year...)
>Now have to clock out for your 30 minute lunch break.
>Have to do a bunch of useless amazon related tasks to help with Amazon-in-store shoppers.
>No gain sharing, meaning no benefit from driving sales.
>Everything shelf is now laid out by corporate, meaning buyers have barely any creative input when it comes to changing product.
If you shop here after 2017, you are a sheep who is throwing away your money just so you can shop with other middle class sheep. It is nice not having to deal with the dregs of society though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18889828
pretty good, i used madigascar vanilla sitting in a liter vodka bottle.
recipe:
2qt half & half
12 egg yolks
2 cup sugar or 1 cup erythritol 1 cup allulose (or xylitol) or 2 cup erythritol if eating within 48 hours
flavor
25 dollar walmart churn https://www.walmart.com/ip/Nostalgia-4-Quart-Electric-Ice-Cream-Maker-Blue/749542584
big boxes of salt

1. put a metal bowl on the stove and dump everything but flavor in it. remember to break yolks. add pinch of salt. turn the heat to maximum and stir it
2. you can do this until either the sugar is fully dissolved or to official guideline which is like 150F to kill salmonella. use infrared thermometer and remember what temperature you turned the heat off at for next time
3. dump ice cream custard into ice cream maker cylinder and put it in the fridge for a few hours
4. make lots of ice sitting in the freezer the day before
5. put cylinder in bucket, put paddle in cylinder, put motor on, dump layer of ice, layer of salt till it's full and plug in
6. churn for about 20-30 min or until it fails to churn. if you used sugar or plain erythritol, it's ready to eat. if you used erythritol with alluose (or xylitol), it needs a day or two in the freezer to get firmer. the bottom is usually ready though.
